awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2021: Inference of the repeated evolution of prothoracic defensive glands in the Tenebrionidae (Coleoptera)
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2021, Integrative Research Investigating the Rules of Life Governing Interactions Between Genomes, Environment and Phenotypes. The fellowship supports research and training of the Fellow that will contribute to the area of Rules of Life in innovative ways.  Insects use chemical secretions for many reasons, including to find food, mates, and defend against predators. Chemical secretions from glands are especially important for self-defense. However, our understanding of how glands evolve to produce specific chemicals from specific body regions is limited. Studying gland function and evolution is essential to understanding the evolution of insect chemical defenses, insect communication, and insects as a whole.  The Fellow will use darkling beetles and their thoracic defensive glands as a model system for testing hypotheses about mechanisms of insect gland evolution. The outcomes of this research will also aid the development of educational materials for public outreach and K-12 students from diverse backgrounds. 

This research primarily aims to address whether prothoracic defensive glands (PDGs) of darkling beetles (Coleoptera: Tenebrionidae), have evolved via parallel or convergent evolution. Specifically, this research aims to examine 1) the genes and gene regulatory networks involved in PDG development across Tenebrionidae, 2) the anatomically homologous features of Tenebrionidae PDGs, and 3) life history traits correlated with PDG evolution. Comparative transcriptomics will be used to compare the gene expression profiles of developing PDGs and glandless body tissue in five representative taxa to identify candidate genes and gene regulatory networks involved in gland development. Morphological investigations examining gland origin points, musculature, locality, gross structure, and ultrastructure will be carried out to examine whether they are derived from homologous or non-homologous tissues. Examining correlations between PDG evolution and life history traits will be carried out using gland occurrence and life history data mined from literature and placed in the context of the latest phylogenetic hypotheses for Tenebrionidae. The Fellow hypothesizes that the PDGs of Tenebrionidae have evolved through parallel evolution (i.e., develop through the co-option of homologous gene regulatory networks and prothoracic tissues), but are not correlated with known life history traits. In addition to collaboration with professional educators, this project will also provide excellent research, training, and scientific communication opportunities for the Fellow as well as for graduate and undergraduate students interested in insect morphology, bioinformatics, and phylogenetics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Insects are unique among animals in the behavioral, physical, and chemical strategies they have evolved for self-defense. The latter have long interested evolutionary biologists given the diversity of cytotoxic compounds deployed. While there has been much work to characterize insect defensive chemicals, the development, morphologies, and evolution of the glands biosynthesizing, storing, and secreting them are less understood despite their importance. Among the most charismatic of the chemically-defended insects are the darkling beetles (Coleoptera: Tenebrionidae), many of which biosynthesize quinones and other compounds using abdominal defensive glands (ADGs), and in some taxa, prothoracic defensive glands (PDGs). Displaying immense morphological diversity and having likely evolved multiple times, darkling beetle AGDs and PDGs represent ideal systems for studying comparative gland morphology and evolutionary development. The overarching goal of this project was to improve our understanding of the patterns and processes underlying exocrine gland evolution in insects using the defensive glands of darkling beetles as model systems.

Specifically, the fellow sought to characterize the genes and gene regulatory networks underlying PDG development. To this end, the fellow sequenced the adult and pupal gland transcriptomes of Tenebrio molitor and Zophobas morio, these taxa representing two robustly independent origins of PDGs. This experiment allowed the fellow to identify genes upregulated during gland development and identify candidates involved in such. Sequencing adult gland transcriptomes primarily allowed for comparisons between developing and fully developed glands to improve developmental gene identification. As a byproduct, this also facilitated the identification of genes upregulated in fully developed glands and, thus, candidates with potential involvement in defensive chemical biosynthesis.

The fellow identified several members of promising gene families as highly expressed and/or upregulated in the developing glands of both species. Perhaps the most notable are several cuticular proteins, which likely in part form the reservoir itself. In each pupal gland transcriptome, cuticular protein genes are members of the upregulated gene set, and several members are some of the most highly expressed in the glands. Furthermore, phylogenetic analyses suggest that of these upregulated and highly-expressed cuticular protein genes, several are orthologous, while others are paralogous. In addition to these genes are several others involved in cellular differentiation and development, including homeodomain-containing genes and, in Zophobas morio especially, epidermal growth factor and zinc finger domain-containing genes. The identification of genes involved in defensive chemical biosynthesis is ongoing.

The fellow also imaged over 300 darkling beetle ADG samples held at the California Academy of Sciences, deposited by Dr. John T. Doyen. This collection is the largest of its kind, with approximately 250 species sampled across nearly 180 genera and 50 tribes, representing most, if not all, gland-bearing subfamilies of Tenebrionidae. Although a portion of this collection was published, approximately 80% of the samples were uncharacterized, and none had been studied in a modern phylogenetic context. Each gland sample has since been carefully inspected, and morphological characters have been and continue to be coded and examined in the context of the most recent classification systems of the family to uncover patterns in the evolution of key morphological traits.

Preliminary results suggest ADGs likely evolved twice in the Tenebrionidae and were lost at least once in the subfamily Phrenapatinae. Within genera and even tribes, gland morphology tends to be relatively conserved, with several exceptions. Certain characters like sclerotized annular rings, reservoir lobes, and elongated reservoirs appear to have evolved several times across the family.

Together, the activities of this fellowship suggest that insect exocrine glands may evolve via convergent and parallel evolutionary mechanisms. Comparative transcriptomics suggests orthologous and paralogous cuticular protein genes may have been co-opted independently for reservoir formation in the PDGs of Tenebrio molitor and Zophobas morio. Morphological studies indicate that features of the ADGs, from annulation to lobes to even the presence and absence of glands, have evolved multiple times. While much work remains to characterize the chemical constituents, biochemical and developmental pathways, functions, and structures of insect defensive glands, this work provides a foundation for future studies investigating such topics. The fellow intends to publish at least two peer-reviewed manuscripts describing these findings in the near future.

In addition to his research, the fellow enjoyed several opportunities to train and receive training in molecular, curatorial, and bioinformatics techniques. Specifically, the fellow hosted several multi-day workshops for graduate students on Nanopore library preparation/sequencing and high-performance cloud computing. The fellow also received significant training in phylogenomics and participated in several projects reconstructing multi-locus phylogenies of darkling beetle genera and tribes using fresh and museum specimens alike. In addition to this experience analyzing museum specimen DNA, the fellow also gained experience working in natural history museums and utilizing advanced microscopy equipment for high-throughput sample imaging. The fellow was also involved in multiple public education events throughout the fellowship.
